          <div id="content" class="mc-content span12">
            <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
              <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                <div id="highlighted" class="clearfix"></div>
                                                <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Queer Poetry in America </h1>
                                                                <div class="tabs">  </div>
                                                                              </div>
                                                        <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <article id="node-10552" class="node node-stanford-course clearfix" about="/courses/2016-2017-english-150j" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Queer Poetry in America" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard" class="postcard group-s-postcard field-group-div"><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard-content" class="postcard-content group-s-postcard-content field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><span>Some poets are known for portraying alternative sexualities in their poetry. Others seem to cover sexuality up. Can we use a poem to determine whether a poet is gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender, or questioning? Or do some poets simply defy categorization? What makes a poem queer? Is poetry somehow more or less queer than other literary forms? Even if we can answer these questions, what would they tell us about literature in general? This course will investigate such topics and more by tracking queer poetry in twentieth-century America. We’ll start with nineteenth-century figures Walt Whitman and Emily Dickinson, then move on to Gertrude Stein, Hart Crane, Langston Hughes, Countee Cullen, Elizabeth Bishop, Allen Ginsberg, Frank O’Hara, and others. We’ll ask what their poetry meant in their own times, as well as what it means to us in our present era of expanding civil rights and changing sexual attitudes.</span></p>
<p> </p>
</div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-coursenum-group" class="course-number summary group-coursenum-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-code field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">150J</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-subject field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">ENGLISH</div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-morelink-group" class="more-link group-morelink-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ec-link field-type-link-field field-label-above"><div class="field-label">ExploreCourses Link:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;q=ENGLISH150J">View this course and available sections on ExploreCourses</a></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-id field-type-number-integer field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Course ID:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">219 066</div></div></div>  </div>
  <ul class="links inline"><li class="comment_forbidden first last"></li>
</ul>  </article>  </div>
                                                                                                                              <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-courses-section-info" class="clearfix block block-views">     <h2>Section Information</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="view view-courses view-id-courses view-display-id-section_info view-dom-id-348cfc142061a040a90dc5b46d088417">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">

    <div id="main-bottom-wrapper" class="main-bottom-wrapper">
            <div class="container">
                        <div id="main-bottom" class="row-fluid main-bottom"> <div class="region region-main-bottom clearfix">
  <div id="block-block-5" class="clearfix block block-block bookmark-bottom span3">       <div class="content"> 
 </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
 </div>
                      </div>
          </div>
    <div id="main-lower-wrapper" class="main-lower-wrapper">
            <div class="container">
                        <div id="main-lower" class="row-fluid main-lower"> <div class="region region-main-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-publications-block-1" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-publications view-id-publications view-display-id-block_1 views-grid-four views-grid-header-footer view-dom-id-fef05a751ae62327d6597ce8a32ab7c5">
            <div class="view-header">
      <h2>Department Bookshelf</h2>
<p>English remains a top-ranked department nationally because of the strength and variety of our faculty publications, both in scholarly research and creative writing. Browse the Bookshelf to explore our many interests.</p>    </div>
  
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-align-center">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-image-info">        <div class="field-content"><a href="/bookshelf/race-and-totalitarian-century-geopolitics-black-literary-imagination"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-small-profile field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/38538" typeof="">

    <div id="main-content-wrapper" class="main-content-wrapper">
      <div class="container">
        <div id="main-content" class="row main-content">
                    <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
          
          <div id="content" class="mc-content span12">
            <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
              <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                <div id="highlighted" class="clearfix"></div>
                                                <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Queer Poetry in America </h1>
                                                                <div class="tabs">  </div>
                                                                              </div>
                                                        <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <article id="node-10552" class="node node-stanford-course clearfix" about="/courses/2016-2017-english-150j" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Queer Poetry in America" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard" class="postcard group-s-postcard field-group-div"><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard-content" class="postcard-content group-s-postcard-content field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><span>Some poets are known for portraying alternative sexualities in their poetry. Others seem to cover sexuality up. Can we use a poem to determine whether a poet is gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender, or questioning? Or do some poets simply defy categorization? What makes a poem queer? Is poetry somehow more or less queer than other literary forms? Even if we can answer these questions, what would they tell us about literature in general? This course will investigate such topics and more by tracking queer poetry in twentieth-century America. We’ll start with nineteenth-century figures Walt Whitman and Emily Dickinson, then move on to Gertrude Stein, Hart Crane, Langston Hughes, Countee Cullen, Elizabeth Bishop, Allen Ginsberg, Frank O’Hara, and others. We’ll ask what their poetry meant in their own times, as well as what it means to us in our present era of expanding civil rights and changing sexual attitudes.</span></p>
<p> </p>
</div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-coursenum-group" class="course-number summary group-coursenum-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-code field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">150J</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-subject field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">ENGLISH</div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-morelink-group" class="more-link group-morelink-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ec-link field-type-link-field field-label-above"><div class="field-label">ExploreCourses Link:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;q=ENGLISH150J">View this course and available sections on ExploreCourses</a></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-id field-type-number-integer field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Course ID:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">219 066</div></div></div>  </div>
  <ul class="links inline"><li class="comment_forbidden first last"></li>
</ul>  </article>  </div>
                                                                                                                              <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">

            <div class="view-header">
      <h2>Department Bookshelf</h2>
<p>English remains a top-ranked department nationally because of the strength and variety of our faculty publications, both in scholarly research and creative writing. Browse the Bookshelf to explore our many interests.</p>    </div>

<div id="block-views-affiliated-programs-block-3" class="clearfix block block-views span2">     <h2>Affiliated Programs</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="view view-affiliated-programs view-id-affiliated_programs view-display-id-block_3 view-dom-id-e57d9e0a376fb40ee1b1b75f510dc48c">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-program-link">        <div class="field-content"><a href="http://creativewriting.stanford.edu/">Creative Writing Program</a></div>  </div>  </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-2 views-row-even">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-program-link">        <div class="field-content"><a href="http://novel.stanford.edu/">Center for the Study of the Novel</a></div>  </div>  </div>

  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-program-link">        <div class="field-content"><a href="https://undergrad.stanford.edu/tutoring-support/hume-center">Hume Center for Writing and Speaking</a></div>  </div>  </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-5 views-row-odd views-row-last">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-program-link">        <div class="field-content"><a href="http://mellonfellowship.stanford.edu/">Andrew W. Mellon Fellowship of Scholars in the Humanities</a></div>  </div>  </div>

    <div id="main-content-wrapper" class="main-content-wrapper">
      <div class="container">
        <div id="main-content" class="row main-content">
                    <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
          
          <div id="content" class="mc-content span12">
            <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
              <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                <div id="highlighted" class="clearfix"></div>
                                                <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Animals and the Fictions of Identity (AMSTUD 175E) </h1>
                                                                <div class="tabs">  </div>
                                                                              </div>
                                                        <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <article id="node-10576" class="node node-stanford-course clearfix" about="/courses/2016-2017-english-175e" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Animals and the Fictions of Identity (AMSTUD 175E)" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard" class="postcard group-s-postcard field-group-div"><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard-content" class="postcard-content group-s-postcard-content field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>In a post-Darwin world, the notion that we might all have an animal alter-ego lurking inside seems quite familiar. But ideas about animals, how they think and feel, act and react, involve identity categories such as race, gender, class and ability in surprising ways. This course will trace the relationship between animality and human life in twentieth-century American fiction, from race and indigeneity in Jack London's dog stories to the storytelling practices of contemporary animal advocacy groups. The course may also include an experiential component in which students will have the opportunity to explore multispecies concerns with a local organization.</p>
</div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-coursenum-group" class="course-number summary group-coursenum-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-code field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">175E</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-subject field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">ENGLISH</div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-morelink-group" class="more-link group-morelink-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ec-link field-type-link-field field-label-above"><div class="field-label">ExploreCourses Link:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;q=ENGLISH175E">View this course and available sections on ExploreCourses</a></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-id field-type-number-integer field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Course ID:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">219 128</div></div></div>  </div>
  <ul class="links inline"><li class="comment_forbidden first last"></li>
</ul>  </article>  </div>
                                                                                                                              <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-courses-section-info" class="clearfix block block-views">     <h2>Section Information</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="view view-courses view-id-courses view-display-id-section_info view-dom-id-ffeb66e953f282e3cdb2cced629f09a9">

         <thead>
      <tr>
                  <th class="views-field views-field-title"  scope="col">

            <a href="/people/victoria-googasian">Victoria Googasian</a>          </td>

            2016-2017 Summer          </td>
                  <td class="views-field views-field-field-s-course-dow" >

  <div id="block-views-publications-block-1" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-publications view-id-publications view-display-id-block_1 views-grid-four views-grid-header-footer view-dom-id-841e75bbcfc0c970ee9f5f65ff6a9e68">
            <div class="view-header">
      <h2>Department Bookshelf</h2>
<p>English remains a top-ranked department nationally because of the strength and variety of our faculty publications, both in scholarly research and creative writing. Browse the Bookshelf to explore our many interests.</p>    </div>
  
  
  
      <div class="view-content">

          <div id="content" class="mc-content span12">
            <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
              <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                <div id="highlighted" class="clearfix"></div>
                                                <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Animals and the Fictions of Identity (AMSTUD 175E) </h1>
                                                                <div class="tabs">  </div>
                                                                              </div>
                                                        <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <article id="node-10576" class="node node-stanford-course clearfix" about="/courses/2016-2017-english-175e" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Animals and the Fictions of Identity (AMSTUD 175E)" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard" class="postcard group-s-postcard field-group-div"><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard-content" class="postcard-content group-s-postcard-content field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>In a post-Darwin world, the notion that we might all have an animal alter-ego lurking inside seems quite familiar. But ideas about animals, how they think and feel, act and react, involve identity categories such as race, gender, class and ability in surprising ways. This course will trace the relationship between animality and human life in twentieth-century American fiction, from race and indigeneity in Jack London's dog stories to the storytelling practices of contemporary animal advocacy groups. The course may also include an experiential component in which students will have the opportunity to explore multispecies concerns with a local organization.</p>
</div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-coursenum-group" class="course-number summary group-coursenum-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-code field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">175E</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-subject field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">ENGLISH</div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-morelink-group" class="more-link group-morelink-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ec-link field-type-link-field field-label-above"><div class="field-label">ExploreCourses Link:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;q=ENGLISH175E">View this course and available sections on ExploreCourses</a></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-id field-type-number-integer field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Course ID:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">219 128</div></div></div>  </div>
  <ul class="links inline"><li class="comment_forbidden first last"></li>
</ul>  </article>  </div>
                                                                                                                              <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">

            <div class="view-header">
      <h2>Department Bookshelf</h2>
<p>English remains a top-ranked department nationally because of the strength and variety of our faculty publications, both in scholarly research and creative writing. Browse the Bookshelf to explore our many interests.</p>    </div>

          <div id="content" class="mc-content span12">
            <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
              <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                <div id="highlighted" class="clearfix"></div>
                                                <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Animals and the Fictions of Identity (AMSTUD 175E) </h1>
                                                                <div class="tabs">  </div>
                                                                              </div>
                                                        <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <article id="node-10576" class="node node-stanford-course clearfix" about="/courses/2016-2017-english-175e" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Animals and the Fictions of Identity (AMSTUD 175E)" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard" class="postcard group-s-postcard field-group-div"><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard-content" class="postcard-content group-s-postcard-content field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>In a post-Darwin world, the notion that we might all have an animal alter-ego lurking inside seems quite familiar. But ideas about animals, how they think and feel, act and react, involve identity categories such as race, gender, class and ability in surprising ways. This course will trace the relationship between animality and human life in twentieth-century American fiction, from race and indigeneity in Jack London's dog stories to the storytelling practices of contemporary animal advocacy groups. The course may also include an experiential component in which students will have the opportunity to explore multispecies concerns with a local organization.</p>
</div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-coursenum-group" class="course-number summary group-coursenum-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-code field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">175E</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-subject field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">ENGLISH</div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-morelink-group" class="more-link group-morelink-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ec-link field-type-link-field field-label-above"><div class="field-label">ExploreCourses Link:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;q=ENGLISH175E">View this course and available sections on ExploreCourses</a></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-id field-type-number-integer field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Course ID:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">219 128</div></div></div>  </div>
  <ul class="links inline"><li class="comment_forbidden first last"></li>
</ul>  </article>  </div>
                                                                                                                              <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">

            <div class="view-header">
      <h2>Department Bookshelf</h2>
<p>English remains a top-ranked department nationally because of the strength and variety of our faculty publications, both in scholarly research and creative writing. Browse the Bookshelf to explore our many interests.</p>    </div>

          <div id="content" class="mc-content span12">
            <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
              <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                <div id="highlighted" class="clearfix"></div>
                                                <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Reading Politics: The History and Future of Literacy </h1>
                                                                <div class="tabs">  </div>
                                                                              </div>
                                                        <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <article id="node-10558" class="node node-stanford-course clearfix" about="/courses/2016-2017-english-180b" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Reading Politics: The History and Future of Literacy" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard" class="postcard group-s-postcard field-group-div"><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard-content" class="postcard-content group-s-postcard-content field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>Reading is a political act. Through our major texts of Charles Dickens's <em>Oliver Twist</em>, Zora Neale Hurston's <em>The Eatonville Anthology</em>, and Azar Nafisi's <em>Reading Lolita in Tehran</em>, we will explore the classed, racialized, and gendered power dynamics of literacy and literature. How can books incite social revolutions? How can they maintain harmful inequalities? When is reading a tool of empowerment and when is it a tool of social control? We will examine these questions in a number of contexts, ranging from Victorian London, to the Jim Crow American South, from the Islamic revolution in Iran to a Silicon Valley proliferating with new forms of scientific, technological, and financial literacy. The course includes a significant service learning component, in which students will volunteer to tutor underprivileged readers through Bay Area literacy programs. Final projects will ask students to reflect on these tutoring experiences and consider the complex politics at work in the act of teaching someone to read.</p>
</div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-coursenum-group" class="course-number summary group-coursenum-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-code field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">180B</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-subject field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">ENGLISH</div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-morelink-group" class="more-link group-morelink-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ec-link field-type-link-field field-label-above"><div class="field-label">ExploreCourses Link:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;q=ENGLISH180B">View this course and available sections on ExploreCourses</a></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-id field-type-number-integer field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Course ID:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">214 397</div></div></div>  </div>
  <ul class="links inline"><li class="comment_forbidden first last"></li>
</ul>  </article>  </div>
                                                                                                                              <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">

            <div class="view-header">
      <h2>Department Bookshelf</h2>
<p>English remains a top-ranked department nationally because of the strength and variety of our faculty publications, both in scholarly research and creative writing. Browse the Bookshelf to explore our many interests.</p>    </div>

    <div id="main" class="clearfix main" role="main">
    <div id="main-top-wrapper" class="main-top-wrapper">
                                        </div>
    <div id="main-content-wrapper" class="main-content-wrapper">
      <div class="container">
        <div id="main-content" class="row main-content">
                    <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
          
          <div id="content" class="mc-content span12">
            <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
              <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                <div id="highlighted" class="clearfix"></div>
                                                <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Reading Politics: The History and Future of Literacy </h1>
                                                                <div class="tabs">  </div>
                                                                              </div>
                                                        <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <article id="node-10558" class="node node-stanford-course clearfix" about="/courses/2016-2017-english-180b" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Reading Politics: The History and Future of Literacy" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard" class="postcard group-s-postcard field-group-div"><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard-content" class="postcard-content group-s-postcard-content field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>Reading is a political act. Through our major texts of Charles Dickens's <em>Oliver Twist</em>, Zora Neale Hurston's <em>The Eatonville Anthology</em>, and Azar Nafisi's <em>Reading Lolita in Tehran</em>, we will explore the classed, racialized, and gendered power dynamics of literacy and literature. How can books incite social revolutions? How can they maintain harmful inequalities? When is reading a tool of empowerment and when is it a tool of social control? We will examine these questions in a number of contexts, ranging from Victorian London, to the Jim Crow American South, from the Islamic revolution in Iran to a Silicon Valley proliferating with new forms of scientific, technological, and financial literacy. The course includes a significant service learning component, in which students will volunteer to tutor underprivileged readers through Bay Area literacy programs. Final projects will ask students to reflect on these tutoring experiences and consider the complex politics at work in the act of teaching someone to read.</p>
</div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-coursenum-group" class="course-number summary group-coursenum-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-code field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">180B</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-subject field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">ENGLISH</div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-morelink-group" class="more-link group-morelink-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ec-link field-type-link-field field-label-above"><div class="field-label">ExploreCourses Link:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;q=ENGLISH180B">View this course and available sections on ExploreCourses</a></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-id field-type-number-integer field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Course ID:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">214 397</div></div></div>  </div>
  <ul class="links inline"><li class="comment_forbidden first last"></li>
</ul>  </article>  </div>
                                                                                                                              <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-courses-section-info" class="clearfix block block-views">     <h2>Section Information</h2>

      <h2>Department Bookshelf</h2>
<p>English remains a top-ranked department nationally because of the strength and variety of our faculty publications, both in scholarly research and creative writing. Browse the Bookshelf to explore our many interests.</p>    </div>

                    <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
          
          <div id="content" class="mc-content span12">
            <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
              <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                <div id="highlighted" class="clearfix"></div>
                                                <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Reading Politics: The History and Future of Literacy </h1>
                                                                <div class="tabs">  </div>
                                                                              </div>
                                                        <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <article id="node-10558" class="node node-stanford-course clearfix" about="/courses/2016-2017-english-180b" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Reading Politics: The History and Future of Literacy" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard" class="postcard group-s-postcard field-group-div"><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard-content" class="postcard-content group-s-postcard-content field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>Reading is a political act. Through our major texts of Charles Dickens's <em>Oliver Twist</em>, Zora Neale Hurston's <em>The Eatonville Anthology</em>, and Azar Nafisi's <em>Reading Lolita in Tehran</em>, we will explore the classed, racialized, and gendered power dynamics of literacy and literature. How can books incite social revolutions? How can they maintain harmful inequalities? When is reading a tool of empowerment and when is it a tool of social control? We will examine these questions in a number of contexts, ranging from Victorian London, to the Jim Crow American South, from the Islamic revolution in Iran to a Silicon Valley proliferating with new forms of scientific, technological, and financial literacy. The course includes a significant service learning component, in which students will volunteer to tutor underprivileged readers through Bay Area literacy programs. Final projects will ask students to reflect on these tutoring experiences and consider the complex politics at work in the act of teaching someone to read.</p>
</div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-coursenum-group" class="course-number summary group-coursenum-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-code field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">180B</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-subject field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">ENGLISH</div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-morelink-group" class="more-link group-morelink-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ec-link field-type-link-field field-label-above"><div class="field-label">ExploreCourses Link:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;q=ENGLISH180B">View this course and available sections on ExploreCourses</a></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-id field-type-number-integer field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Course ID:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">214 397</div></div></div>  </div>
  <ul class="links inline"><li class="comment_forbidden first last"></li>
</ul>  </article>  </div>
                                                                                                                              <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">

            <div class="view-header">
      <h2>Department Bookshelf</h2>
<p>English remains a top-ranked department nationally because of the strength and variety of our faculty publications, both in scholarly research and creative writing. Browse the Bookshelf to explore our many interests.</p>    </div>

  <div class="edit-link">        <span></span>  </div>  </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-4 views-row-even views-row-last views-align-center">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-image-info">        <div class="field-content"><a href="/bookshelf/social-imperative-race-close-reading-and-contemporary-literary-criticism"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-small-profile field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/37302" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://english.stanford.edu/sites/default/files/styles/sm-profile/public/inprint_moya.jpg?itok=APQgLIad" width="100" height="130" alt="" /></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></a></div>  </div>  
  <div class="views-field views-field-title">        <span class="field-content"><a href="/bookshelf/social-imperative-race-close-reading-and-contemporary-literary-criticism">The Social Imperative: Race, Close Reading, and Contemporary Literary Criticism</a></span>  </div>  
  <div class="edit-link">        <span></span>  </div>  </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
      <div class="view-footer">

                              <div id="nav-search" class="nav-search"> <div class="region region-search-box clearfix">
  <div id="block-search-form" class="clearfix block block-search" role="search">       <div class="content"> <form action="/courses/2016-2017-english-244" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline">
      <h2 class="element-invisible">Search form</h2>

            <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
              <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                <div id="highlighted" class="clearfix"></div>
                                                <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> 101 Years of London </h1>
                                                                <div class="tabs">  </div>
                                                                              </div>
                                                        <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <article id="node-10358" class="node node-stanford-course clearfix" about="/courses/2016-2017-english-244" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="101 Years of London" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard" class="postcard group-s-postcard field-group-div"><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard-content" class="postcard-content group-s-postcard-content field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>101 Years of London juxtaposes older representations of the UK's capital city (from Defoe, Dickens, Woolf and others) with contemporary accounts (from Zadie Smith, Ian McEwen and others). We will also look at films, painting, photography and websites about London.</p>
</div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-coursenum-group" class="course-number summary group-coursenum-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-code field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">244</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-subject field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">ENGLISH</div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-morelink-group" class="more-link group-morelink-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ec-link field-type-link-field field-label-above"><div class="field-label">ExploreCourses Link:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;q=ENGLISH244">View this course and available sections on ExploreCourses</a></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-id field-type-number-integer field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Course ID:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">218 059</div></div></div>  </div>
  <ul class="links inline"><li class="comment_forbidden first last"></li>
</ul>  </article>  </div>
                                                                                                                              <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">

  <div id="block-views-publications-block-1" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-publications view-id-publications view-display-id-block_1 views-grid-four views-grid-header-footer view-dom-id-fef05a751ae62327d6597ce8a32ab7c5">
            <div class="view-header">
      <h2>Department Bookshelf</h2>
<p>English remains a top-ranked department nationally because of the strength and variety of our faculty publications, both in scholarly research and creative writing. Browse the Bookshelf to explore our many interests.</p>    </div>

            <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
              <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                <div id="highlighted" class="clearfix"></div>
                                                <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> 101 Years of London </h1>
                                                                <div class="tabs">  </div>
                                                                              </div>
                                                        <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <article id="node-10358" class="node node-stanford-course clearfix" about="/courses/2016-2017-english-244" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="101 Years of London" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard" class="postcard group-s-postcard field-group-div"><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard-content" class="postcard-content group-s-postcard-content field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>101 Years of London juxtaposes older representations of the UK's capital city (from Defoe, Dickens, Woolf and others) with contemporary accounts (from Zadie Smith, Ian McEwen and others). We will also look at films, painting, photography and websites about London.</p>
</div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-coursenum-group" class="course-number summary group-coursenum-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-code field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">244</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-subject field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">ENGLISH</div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-morelink-group" class="more-link group-morelink-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ec-link field-type-link-field field-label-above"><div class="field-label">ExploreCourses Link:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;q=ENGLISH244">View this course and available sections on ExploreCourses</a></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-id field-type-number-integer field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Course ID:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">218 059</div></div></div>  </div>
  <ul class="links inline"><li class="comment_forbidden first last"></li>
</ul>  </article>  </div>
                                                                                                                              <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">

                        <div id="main-lower" class="row-fluid main-lower"> <div class="region region-main-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-publications-block-1" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-publications view-id-publications view-display-id-block_1 views-grid-four views-grid-header-footer view-dom-id-fef05a751ae62327d6597ce8a32ab7c5">
            <div class="view-header">
      <h2>Department Bookshelf</h2>
<p>English remains a top-ranked department nationally because of the strength and variety of our faculty publications, both in scholarly research and creative writing. Browse the Bookshelf to explore our many interests.</p>    </div>
  
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-align-center">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-image-info">        <div class="field-content"><a href="/bookshelf/race-and-totalitarian-century-geopolitics-black-literary-imagination"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-small-profile field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/38538" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://english.stanford.edu/sites/default/files/styles/sm-profile/public/rasberry-book.jpg?itok=pOjzfnaf" width="100" height="130" alt="" /></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></a></div>  </div>  
  <div class="views-field views-field-title">        <span class="field-content"><a href="/bookshelf/race-and-totalitarian-century-geopolitics-black-literary-imagination">Race and the Totalitarian Century: Geopolitics in the Black Literary Imagination</a></span>  </div>  
  <div class="edit-link">        <span></span>  </div>  </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-2 views-row-even views-align-center">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-image-info">        <div class="field-content"><a href="/bookshelf/or-orwell-writing-and-democratic-socialism"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-small-profile field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/37300" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://english.stanford.edu/sites/default/files/styles/sm-profile/public/inprint_woloch.jpg?itok=-PO3dLCs" width="100" height="130" alt="" /></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></a></div>  </div>  
  <div class="views-field views-field-title">        <span class="field-content"><a href="/bookshelf/or-orwell-writing-and-democratic-socialism">Or Orwell: Writing and Democratic Socialism</a></span>  </div>  
  <div class="edit-link">        <span></span>  </div>  </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-3 views-row-odd views-align-center">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-image-info">        <div class="field-content"><a href="/bookshelf/writing-america-literary-landmarks-walden-pond-wounded-knee-readers-companion"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-small-profile field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/37243" typeof="">
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-field-s-image-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://english.stanford.edu/sites/default/files/styles/sm-profile/public/shelley.png?itok=vLIofX2z" width="100" height="130" alt="" /></div></div></div>  </div>
</div>
</div></a></div>  </div>  
  <div class="views-field views-field-title">        <span class="field-content"><a href="/bookshelf/writing-america-literary-landmarks-walden-pond-wounded-knee-readers-companion">Writing America: Literary Landmarks from Walden Pond to Wounded Knee (A Reader&#039;s Companion)</a></span>  </div>  
  <div class="edit-link">        <span></span>  </div>  </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-4 views-row-even views-row-last views-align-center">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-image-info">        <div class="field-content"><a href="/bookshelf/social-imperative-race-close-reading-and-contemporary-literary-criticism"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-small-profile field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/37302" typeof="">

    <div id="main-content-wrapper" class="main-content-wrapper">
      <div class="container">
        <div id="main-content" class="row main-content">
                    <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
          
          <div id="content" class="mc-content span12">
            <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
              <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                <div id="highlighted" class="clearfix"></div>
                                                <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> 101 Years of London </h1>
                                                                <div class="tabs">  </div>
                                                                              </div>
                                                        <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <article id="node-10358" class="node node-stanford-course clearfix" about="/courses/2016-2017-english-244" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="101 Years of London" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard" class="postcard group-s-postcard field-group-div"><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard-content" class="postcard-content group-s-postcard-content field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>101 Years of London juxtaposes older representations of the UK's capital city (from Defoe, Dickens, Woolf and others) with contemporary accounts (from Zadie Smith, Ian McEwen and others). We will also look at films, painting, photography and websites about London.</p>
</div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-coursenum-group" class="course-number summary group-coursenum-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-code field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">244</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-subject field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">ENGLISH</div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-morelink-group" class="more-link group-morelink-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ec-link field-type-link-field field-label-above"><div class="field-label">ExploreCourses Link:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;q=ENGLISH244">View this course and available sections on ExploreCourses</a></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-id field-type-number-integer field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Course ID:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">218 059</div></div></div>  </div>
  <ul class="links inline"><li class="comment_forbidden first last"></li>
</ul>  </article>  </div>
                                                                                                                              <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-courses-section-info" class="clearfix block block-views">     <h2>Section Information</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="view view-courses view-id-courses view-display-id-section_info view-dom-id-4d8bf46c07153cc64fee283728f30a5e">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
      <table class="views-table cols-4" >
         <thead>
      <tr>
                  <th class="views-field views-field-title active"  scope="col">
            <a href="/courses/2016-2017-english-244?order=title&amp;sort=asc" title="sort by Title" class="active">Title<img typeof="foaf:Image" src="https://english.stanford.edu/misc/arrow-asc.png" width="13" height="13" alt="sort ascending" title="sort ascending" /></a>          </th>
                  <th class="views-field views-field-field-s-course-person"  scope="col">
            Instructor          </th>
                  <th class="views-field views-field-field-s-course-section-year"  scope="col">
            Quarter          </th>
                  <th class="views-field views-field-field-s-course-dow"  scope="col">
            Day, Time, Location          </th>
              </tr>
    </thead>
    <tbody>
          <tr class="odd views-row-first views-row-last">
                  <td class="views-field views-field-title active" >
            ENGLISH 244 (section 1)<br /><strong>101 Years of London</strong><br /><strong></strong>          </td>
                  <td class="views-field views-field-field-s-course-person" >
            <a href="/people/nicholas-jenkins">Nicholas Jenkins</a>          </td>
                  <td class="views-field views-field-field-s-course-section-year" >
            2016-2017 Spring          </td>
                  <td class="views-field views-field-field-s-course-dow" >
            <div>Tuesday Thursday</div><div>3:00pm - 4:50pm</div><div>200-105</div><a href="https://english.stanford.edu/sites/default/files/courses/syllabus/101_years_of_london_2017_preliminary_syllabus.pdf">Download Syllabus</a>          </td>

                        <div id="main-lower" class="row-fluid main-lower"> <div class="region region-main-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-publications-block-1" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-publications view-id-publications view-display-id-block_1 views-grid-four views-grid-header-footer view-dom-id-fef05a751ae62327d6597ce8a32ab7c5">
            <div class="view-header">
      <h2>Department Bookshelf</h2>
<p>English remains a top-ranked department nationally because of the strength and variety of our faculty publications, both in scholarly research and creative writing. Browse the Bookshelf to explore our many interests.</p>    </div>
  
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-align-center">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-image-info">        <div class="field-content"><a href="/bookshelf/race-and-totalitarian-century-geopolitics-black-literary-imagination"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-small-profile field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/38538" typeof="">

</div>
</div></a></div>  </div>  
  <div class="views-field views-field-title">        <span class="field-content"><a href="/bookshelf/race-and-totalitarian-century-geopolitics-black-literary-imagination">Race and the Totalitarian Century: Geopolitics in the Black Literary Imagination</a></span>  </div>

                <div id="highlighted" class="clearfix"></div>
                                                <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Fiction Writing </h1>
                                                                <div class="tabs">  </div>
                                                                              </div>
                                                        <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <article id="node-10188" class="node node-stanford-course clearfix" about="/courses/2016-2017-english-90" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Fiction Writing" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard" class="postcard group-s-postcard field-group-div"><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard-content" class="postcard-content group-s-postcard-content field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>The elements of fiction writing: narration, description, and dialogue. Students write complete stories and participate in story workshops. May be repeated for credit. Prerequisite: PWR 1 (waived in summer quarter).</p>
</div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-coursenum-group" class="course-number summary group-coursenum-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-code field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">90</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-subject field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">ENGLISH</div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-morelink-group" class="more-link group-morelink-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ec-link field-type-link-field field-label-above"><div class="field-label">ExploreCourses Link:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;q=ENGLISH90">View this course and available sections on ExploreCourses</a></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ger field-type-text field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Requirements:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">WAY-A-II, WAY-CE</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-id field-type-number-integer field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Course ID:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">113 753</div></div></div>  </div>
  <ul class="links inline"><li class="comment_forbidden first last"></li>
</ul>  </article>  </div>
                                                                                                                              <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">

    <div id="main-lower-wrapper" class="main-lower-wrapper">
            <div class="container">
                        <div id="main-lower" class="row-fluid main-lower"> <div class="region region-main-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-publications-block-1" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-publications view-id-publications view-display-id-block_1 views-grid-four views-grid-header-footer view-dom-id-fef05a751ae62327d6597ce8a32ab7c5">
            <div class="view-header">
      <h2>Department Bookshelf</h2>
<p>English remains a top-ranked department nationally because of the strength and variety of our faculty publications, both in scholarly research and creative writing. Browse the Bookshelf to explore our many interests.</p>    </div>
  
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-align-center">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-image-info">        <div class="field-content"><a href="/bookshelf/race-and-totalitarian-century-geopolitics-black-literary-imagination"><div class="field-collection-view clearfix view-mode-stanford-small-profile field-collection-view-final"><div class="entity entity-field-collection-item field-collection-item-field-s-image-info clearfix" about="/field-collection/field-s-image-info/38538" typeof="">

</div>
</div></a></div>  </div>

                <div id="highlighted" class="clearfix"></div>
                                                <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Fiction Writing </h1>
                                                                <div class="tabs">  </div>
                                                                              </div>
                                                        <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <article id="node-10188" class="node node-stanford-course clearfix" about="/courses/2016-2017-english-90" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Fiction Writing" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard" class="postcard group-s-postcard field-group-div"><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard-content" class="postcard-content group-s-postcard-content field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>The elements of fiction writing: narration, description, and dialogue. Students write complete stories and participate in story workshops. May be repeated for credit. Prerequisite: PWR 1 (waived in summer quarter).</p>
</div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-coursenum-group" class="course-number summary group-coursenum-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-code field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">90</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-subject field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">ENGLISH</div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-morelink-group" class="more-link group-morelink-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ec-link field-type-link-field field-label-above"><div class="field-label">ExploreCourses Link:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;q=ENGLISH90">View this course and available sections on ExploreCourses</a></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ger field-type-text field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Requirements:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">WAY-A-II, WAY-CE</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-id field-type-number-integer field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Course ID:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">113 753</div></div></div>  </div>
  <ul class="links inline"><li class="comment_forbidden first last"></li>
</ul>  </article>  </div>
                                                                                                                              <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-courses-section-info" class="clearfix block block-views">     <h2>Section Information</h2>

          <tr class="even">

                        <div id="main-lower" class="row-fluid main-lower"> <div class="region region-main-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-publications-block-1" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-publications view-id-publications view-display-id-block_1 views-grid-four views-grid-header-footer view-dom-id-fef05a751ae62327d6597ce8a32ab7c5">
            <div class="view-header">
      <h2>Department Bookshelf</h2>
<p>English remains a top-ranked department nationally because of the strength and variety of our faculty publications, both in scholarly research and creative writing. Browse the Bookshelf to explore our many interests.</p>    </div>

        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-program-link">        <div class="field-content"><a href="http://creativewriting.stanford.edu/">Creative Writing Program</a></div>  </div>  </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-2 views-row-even">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-program-link">        <div class="field-content"><a href="http://novel.stanford.edu/">Center for the Study of the Novel</a></div>  </div>  </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-3 views-row-odd">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-program-link">        <div class="field-content"><a href="http://litlab.stanford.edu/">Stanford Literary Lab</a></div>  </div>  </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-4 views-row-even">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-program-link">        <div class="field-content"><a href="https://undergrad.stanford.edu/tutoring-support/hume-center">Hume Center for Writing and Speaking</a></div>  </div>  </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-5 views-row-odd views-row-last">
      
  <div class="views-field views-field-field-s-program-link">        <div class="field-content"><a href="http://mellonfellowship.stanford.edu/">Andrew W. Mellon Fellowship of Scholars in the Humanities</a></div>  </div>  </div>

          <div id="content" class="mc-content span12">
            <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
              <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                <div id="highlighted" class="clearfix"></div>
                                                <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Fiction Writing </h1>
                                                                <div class="tabs">  </div>
                                                                              </div>
                                                        <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <article id="node-10188" class="node node-stanford-course clearfix" about="/courses/2016-2017-english-90" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Fiction Writing" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard" class="postcard group-s-postcard field-group-div"><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard-content" class="postcard-content group-s-postcard-content field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>The elements of fiction writing: narration, description, and dialogue. Students write complete stories and participate in story workshops. May be repeated for credit. Prerequisite: PWR 1 (waived in summer quarter).</p>
</div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-coursenum-group" class="course-number summary group-coursenum-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-code field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">90</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-subject field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">ENGLISH</div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-morelink-group" class="more-link group-morelink-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ec-link field-type-link-field field-label-above"><div class="field-label">ExploreCourses Link:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;q=ENGLISH90">View this course and available sections on ExploreCourses</a></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ger field-type-text field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Requirements:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">WAY-A-II, WAY-CE</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-id field-type-number-integer field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Course ID:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">113 753</div></div></div>  </div>
  <ul class="links inline"><li class="comment_forbidden first last"></li>
</ul>  </article>  </div>
                                                                                                                              <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-courses-section-info" class="clearfix block block-views">     <h2>Section Information</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="view view-courses view-id-courses view-display-id-section_info view-dom-id-7ce5ca55ef1809ade2e14b4c980ddcfb">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
      <table class="views-table cols-4" >
         <thead>
      <tr>
                  <th class="views-field views-field-title active"  scope="col">

  <div id="block-views-publications-block-1" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-publications view-id-publications view-display-id-block_1 views-grid-four views-grid-header-footer view-dom-id-fef05a751ae62327d6597ce8a32ab7c5">
            <div class="view-header">
      <h2>Department Bookshelf</h2>
<p>English remains a top-ranked department nationally because of the strength and variety of our faculty publications, both in scholarly research and creative writing. Browse the Bookshelf to explore our many interests.</p>    </div>

                <div id="highlighted" class="clearfix"></div>
                                                <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Fiction Writing </h1>
                                                                <div class="tabs">  </div>
                                                                              </div>
                                                        <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <article id="node-10562" class="node node-stanford-course clearfix" about="/courses/2016-2017-english-90v-0" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Fiction Writing" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard" class="postcard group-s-postcard field-group-div"><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-s-postcard-content" class="postcard-content group-s-postcard-content field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>Online workshop course that explores the ways in which writers of fiction have used language to examine the world, to create compelling characters, and to move readers. We will begin by studying a selection of stories that demonstrate the many techniques writers use to create fictional worlds; we'll use these stories as models for writing exercises and short assignments, leading to a full story draft.  We will study figurative language, character and setting development, and dramatic structure, among other elements of story craft. Then, each student will submit a full draft and receive feedback from the instructor and his/her classmates.  This course is taught entirely online, but retains the feel of a traditional classroom.  Optional synchronous elements such as discussion and virtual office hours provide the student direct interaction with both the instructor and his/her classmates.  Feedback on written work, both offered to and given by the student, is essential to the course and creates class rapport.</p>
</div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-coursenum-group" class="course-number summary group-coursenum-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-code field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">90V</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-subject field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">ENGLISH</div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="node-stanford-course-full-group-morelink-group" class="more-link group-morelink-group field-group-div"><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-ec-link field-type-link-field field-label-above"><div class="field-label">ExploreCourses Link:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;filter-coursestatus-Active=on&amp;q=ENGLISH90V">View this course and available sections on ExploreCourses</a></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-s-course-id field-type-number-integer field-label-above"><div class="field-label">Course ID:&nbsp;</div><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">216 886</div></div></div>  </div>
  <ul class="links inline"><li class="comment_forbidden first last"></li>
</ul>  </article>  </div>
                                                                                                                              <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">

            <div class="view-header">
      <h2>Department Bookshelf</h2>
<p>English remains a top-ranked department nationally because of the strength and variety of our faculty publications, both in scholarly research and creative writing. Browse the Bookshelf to explore our many interests.</p>    </div>
